text: directors of the National Park in
eastern Chad they had heard rumors of a
massacre of elephants they were about
300 miles away from the massacre zone so
I was about 75 miles away and they asked
me if I could fly over there and see if
the reports were true
we tracked elephant tracks into the area
and then found the massacre zone just
piles of bones that were left because
the meat had been extracted there are
large pools of blood on the ground that
you could still see from so many animals
and we were able to confirm that about a
hundred animals had indeed been been
massacred in that site for so many
elephants to go down you know you'd see
20 or 30 animals in a group that had
obviously gone down together it had to
be modern weapons to take them down that
quickly the machine guns not kind of
thing absolutely now it's just got
retching when you see something of that
extent you know whether it's in a war
where humans are taken down or whether
it's where animals are taken down it's
still just a sinking feeling in your
stomach that is terrible but you did
hear that one elephant might have
survived and the director of Wildlife
for Chad contacted me and said there are
rumors of a baby elephant that had
survived but the rumors that were coming
in had this elephant that you know a
hundred miles apart in different
villages and so it was difficult to
confirm and it took a couple more days
to actually get solid information as to
the location of baby elephant what
happened when you found the elephant it
was tied up to a tree where it had been
for the last at least three to four days
it was getting weak but also very angry
because it had just been tied up to the
tree and kids would come by and no doubt
throw sticks and rocks at it so when I
initially approached it it was trying to
bite it was raising its trunk is trying
to charge a little bit but I just got
slowly staying with it and mixed up some
formula that we had
us to feed it and within the course of
about 30 minutes it was at least
accepting of me and we were able to load
it into a vehicle then and take it back
to the airstrip and then you had to get
it into the plane and I'm guessing the
planes not very big you know it was a
small Cessna 172 a four-seater aircraft
and how big was the elephant the
elephant was somewhere in the vicinity
of about 350 pounds so it was quite the
chore and when I first saw the elephant
in fact I was a little bit concerned
because the rumors we had was that was
much smaller but in fact it was about a
nine-month old Navy elephant so we lured
it in close to the aircraft with the
milk bottle and finally were able to
lift it in with several guys there we
just lifted it into the plane and it was
a tight fit and did the elephant play
any part in flying the plane it was to
be difficult to control it an animal
that size you can actually feel its
weight shifting in the aircraft and I
had to have some restraining straps so
it couldn't go all the way back
otherwise it would go outside of our
control more range but he was quite
interested in playing with my controls
at some point he would put his trunk
forward and feel my hands and touch the
controls and of course feel my face is a
bit of a distraction but at the same
time a very unique experience I guess
were you able to look after the baby
elephant once you've got it back to your
compound once we got to our base of
course the challenge was unloading the
elephant and then we essentially took it
out to the bush we have you know natural
habitat they're still within our
compound and for the next 10 days it was
literally a 24-hour care between my wife
and myself but unfortunately I believe
that the elephant sadly died in the end
it was eight days post Massacre that we
finally reached him and he had become
quite weakened by being away from his
mother for that long but also he had
quite a severe infection on his neck
from the rope that he was tied to the
tree with but also the the main factor
is GUID received cow's milk by some good
intention people but cow's milk is
actually quite toxic to
along with the traumatic experience he
had been through to see his whole family
massacred and everything compounded
unfortunately he did not survive
you know we had pulled out all the stops
we had done everything possible taking
care of a baby starred elephant is very
similar to taking care of starved human
babies that protocols the procedures
very similar did you give him a name we
named him max why we were riding in the
pickup back to the aircraft actually
because it was taking everything we
could muster to keep him in the back of
this pickup over the bouncy roads and
then of course maxing out the the weight
of our airplane for takeoff and
everything so he affectionately got
called max
